toxins.description:
in cats:
    ◦ Cell Division Inhibition: Colchicine acts as an anti-mitotic agent, meaning it inhibits cell division.
    ◦ Systemic Failure: Because it stops cells from dividing, it rapidly affects the body's critical systems, leading to bone marrow suppression, respiratory failure, and multi-organ damage (specifically liver and kidney failure).
    ◦ Gastrointestinal Hemorrhage: It causes severe, often bloody, gastrointestinal bleeding.
toxins.concentration_notes: ◦ High Potency: The Autumn Crocus is extremely dangerous; ingestion of even small amounts can cause severe illness or death.

toxins.name: Specific compounds are not named in the provided texts, though they are described as general irritants capable of causing toxicity

toxins.concentration_notes: ◦ Mild to Moderate: Compared to the Autumn Crocus, the Spring Crocus is less severe. It typically does not cause the systemic organ failure associated with colchicine, though veterinary attention is still recommended if ingested.

2. Autumn Crocus (Colchicum autumnale)
The Autumn Crocus (also known as Meadow Saffron) is highly toxic and potentially fatal. It contains colchicine, a toxin that inhibits rapid cell division, affecting multiple body systems.
A. Severe Gastrointestinal Hemorrhage

symptoms.name: Bloody Vomiting and Diarrhea; Oral Irritation
symptoms.notes: Early signs may include drooling (ptyalism), burning in the mouth, abdominal pain, and difficulty swallowing. The condition progresses to severe hemorrhagic gastritis (bleeding in the stomach) and bloody diarrhea.B. Organ Failure (Liver and Kidney)

symptoms.name: Liver damage (Hepatic necrosis) and Kidney failure
symptoms.onset: Delayed (can take days to manifest fully).
symptoms.notes: Signs of renal issues may include increased thirst, blood in the urine, or a complete failure to pass urine (anuria). Liver damage is a primary contributor to fatality.C. Bone Marrow Suppression

symptoms.name: Bone Marrow Suppression
symptoms.notes: The toxin colchicine stops cells from dividing, which severely impacts the bone marrow's ability to produce blood cells.D. Respiratory Distress

symptoms.name: Respiratory Failure / Difficulty Breathing
symptoms.notes: Respiratory collapse is a cited cause of death in severe cases.E. Neurological and Systemic Signs

symptoms.name: Seizures, Tremors, Shock, and Weakness
symptoms.onset: Variable; shock signs include abnormal heart rates and pale gums.
symptoms.notes: Animals may exhibit signs of shock, such as weakness and lethargy. Seizures and ataxia (loss of balance) can occur as the toxicity progresses.

treatments.name: Gastric Lavage (Stomach Pumping) or Activated Charcoal
treatments.description: Because colchicine (the toxin in Autumn Crocus) is slowly excreted and highly potent, veterinarians may perform gastric lavage to wash toxic plant material out of the stomach. This is often followed by the administration of activated charcoal, which binds to the toxin in the gut to reduce absorption.
treatments.notes: This step is critical because colchicine inhibits cell division and causes multi-organ failure. Immediate removal of the toxin is the most effective way to prevent lethal systemic absorption.Aggressive Fluid Therapy (IV Fluids)

treatments.name: Intravenous (IV) Fluid Resuscitation
treatments.description: The administration of IV fluids is used to correct dehydration and electrolyte imbalances caused by severe vomiting and diarrhea. It also helps support kidney function and maintains blood pressure (combatting shock).
treatments.notes: Autumn Crocus toxicity leads to severe fluid loss and shock. Fluid therapy is essential to stabilize the cat’s circulation and manage the "circulatory disturbances" associated with colchicine poisoning.Symptomatic Management (Pain and GI Control)

treatments.name: Administration of Analgesics and Atropine
treatments.description: Veterinarians may administer analgesics to relieve severe abdominal pain and atropine to manage persistent diarrhea and abdominal cramping.
treatments.notes: Ingestion often causes severe gastrointestinal bleeding and pain. Managing these symptoms is vital for the animal's comfort and stability while the body attempts to process the toxin.Systemic Support (Respiratory and CNS)

treatments.name: Respiratory and Central Nervous System (CNS) Support
treatments.description: In severe cases, the cat may require oxygen therapy or medication to manage respiratory distress and central nervous system disturbances.
treatments.notes:
Death from Autumn Crocus poisoning often results from respiratory failure. Close monitoring of breathing and heart rate is required throughout the recovery process.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Note on Spring Crocus (Crocus spp.)
If the plant is identified as a Spring Crocus, the toxicity is generally limited to gastrointestinal upset.
• Treatment: Veterinary care is usually supportive, focusing on hydration and monitoring for vomiting and diarrhea. It does not typically require the aggressive decontamination protocols used for Autumn Crocus.
